bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, October 14, 1937

div1.p: Hench informs Hutchison about Kissinger's situation, and that he plans to publish the recollections of both Kissinger and Moran.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, October 14, 1937
div1.opener:
October 14, 1937
Dr. Ralph C. Hutchison
Washington and Jefferson College
Washington, Pennsylvania
My dear Hutch:
div1.p:
Thank you so much for sending me the various notes about
Harriet. I have kept Dr. Logan informed, and we were delighted with
the outcome.

I have been meaning to write you for a long time about
my investigation of the yellow fever survivors who worked with Reed.
I have had an interesting correspondence with the only two private
soldiers who are still living and who worked with Reed, Carroll, and
Lazear. As a matter of fact, I believe these two men are the only two
survivors of the whole group. One is in Havana, the other is in Hunting-
ton, Indiana. How are the plans for your celebration coming on? I had
a letter yesterday from Mr. Kissinger, the first man to be given yellow
fever. He is going to Florida for the winter, but expects to speak
again on the radio the twenty-fifth of this month. I don't know what
program. If you wish to know, I'll find out. This is the third time
he has spoken on a national hookup regarding his yellow fever experiments.
We are hoping to have him come here before or after his Florida trip to
tell us about it. As I told you, he is not a polished speaker, and makes
many mistakes in grammar, but has a most interesting story and is a
nice short of a chap, very interesting to me. Neither Kissinger nor
Moran have ever written up their own experiences. Both have given me a
considerable amount of material and I hope to write them up and publish
them under their own names and not mine. Their stories should be
published in as near their own words as possible, in a medical historical
journal.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
